questions.text: A neonate with a history of respiratory difficulty, stridor since birth, has been evaluated by microlaryngobronchoscopy. The laryngeal image is shown in the picture. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the image and symptoms, the probable diagnosis is Congenital Subglottic Hemangioma.

Subglottic Hemangioma

  • A vascular tumour of the subglottic region
  • Though congenital in origin, symptoms typically appear at 3-6 months of age as the lesion enlarges.
  • A key differential diagnosis in infants with progressive stridor
  • A rare cause of infantile airway obstruction
  • Often mistaken for croup or recurrent laryngitis in early stages
  • About 50% of patients have associated cutaneous hemangiomas, typically in the "beard distribution" (chin, neck, lower face)

Clinical Features

  • Stridor (inspiratory or biphasic) appears later than in congenital subglottic stenosis.
  • Cry is normal (vocal cords are not involved)
  • Symptoms worsen with agitation, crying, or infection due to increased venous filling of the hemangioma
  • May present with:
    • Respiratory distress
    • Retractions
    • Recurrent croup-like episodes
  • Feeding difficulties may be present in severe cases

Endoscopic Findings

  • Direct laryngoscopy shows a reddish-blue, compressible, vascular mass in the subglottic area.
  • The lesion may be unilateral or bilateral
  • Biopsy is rarely needed due to the risk of bleeding
  • Occasionally, hemangiomas may extend into the mediastinum (mediastinal hemangiomas)

Treatment

  • In mild/moderate cases or when the airway is severely obstructed, a tracheostomy may be performed to bypass the lesion.
  • The common first-line approach in symptomatic patients is with steroids such as dexamethasone: 1 mg/kg/day for 1 week, followed by Prednisolone: 3 mg/kg/day in divided doses, continued for up to 1 year.
  • CO2 Laser Excision is effective for small, localised lesions
  • Propranolol (2 mg/kg/day) has largely replaced steroids as first-line therapy
  • Requires monitoring for bradycardia and hypoglycemia
  • With appropriate airway management and medical therapy, the prognosis is excellent

Explanation for other options:

Laryngomalacia (Option A): Involves supraglottic flaccidity, not subglottic mass; laryngoscopy shows omega-shaped epiglottis with supraglottic collapse, not a vascular mass.

Congenital Subglottic Stenosis (Option B): A fixed narrowing below the vocal cords due to cartilaginous/fibrous thickening, not a vascular lesion; endoscopy shows circumferential narrowing, not a reddish mass.

Laryngocoele (Option D): Arises from the laryngeal saccule and usually presents in older individuals, not neonates, appears as an air-filled swelling, not a vascular mass.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child developed persistent dyspnea and stridor after an episode of upper respiratory infection. The cry of the baby is normal. On CT scan of the neck, the subglottic diameter is 2.5 mm. He did not show any improvement in the next 6 months. Subsequently, the child has been operated for an airway surgery and a silicone tube (given in the picture) has been placed in the airway. What is the name of this tube?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of congenital subglottic stenosis.

  • Montgomery's silicone tracheal T tube is used for laryngotracheal reconstruction surgery in this patient.
  • This tube is used to support the reconstructed segment for 6 weeks.

Explanation for other options:

The Chevalier Jackson tube (Option B): It is a metallic tracheostomy tube with an inner tube longer than the outer tube.

Fuller's tracheostomy tube (Option C): It is a metallic tracheostomy tube that has one advantage due to the fenestration of the inner tube and the biflanged outer tube, allowing the possibility that the patient may be able to speak with the tracheostomy tube in situ.

Cuffed tracheostomy tubes (Option D): These have cuffs that prevent aspiration.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child has developed persistent dyspnea and stridor since birth. On CT scan of the neck, the subglottic diameter is less than normal with 60% obstruction. What is the appropriate Cotton Myer grading of this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given patient, the subglottic diameter is less than normal, with 60% obstruction. So, it comes under Grade II congenital subglottic stenosis based on Cotton-Meyer Grading.

questions.text: A 23-year-old young man who is a member of a music band has played saxophone for the last 10 years. The band has been doing many popular concerts. He has developed a neck swelling on the left side of the larynx. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the picture. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a typical case of laryngocele.

Etiology

  • A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule, which communicates with the laryngeal lumen.
  • Predisposing factors:
    • Increased intralaryngeal pressure (e.g., playing wind instruments: trumpet, saxophone, etc.)
    • Chronic cough or straining
    • May be congenital or acquired

Pathophysiology

  • The saccule is a mucosal outpouching from the ventricle of the larynx, situated between the true vocal cords (TVC) and false vocal cords (FVC).
  • When the saccule becomes abnormally dilated and air-filled, it forms a laryngocele.
  • The laryngocele may:
    • Remain internal (confined within the larynx)
    • Extend externally through the thyrohyoid membrane to present as a neck swelling (external laryngocele)
    • Or be mixed (both internal and external components)

Clinical Features

  • Bryce's Sign: Compression of the swelling produces a hissing sound of air leakage
  • Intermittent swelling that may enlarge during:
    • Valsalva maneuver
    • Coughing
    • Blowing
  • May cause hoarseness, dysphagia, or airway obstruction in internal or large mixed types

Investigations

  • X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view) during Valsalva manoeuvre:
    • Shows an air-filled, thin-walled swelling lateral to the larynx
  • CT scan:
    • More accurate in defining the extent (internal vs external vs mixed)
  • Laryngoscopy:
    • May show bulging of the ventricular fold or false cord

Management

  • Symptomatic or large laryngocele:
    • Surgical excision (via endoscopic or external approach, depending on type)
    • Microlaryngoscopic resection for internal laryngocele
    • External approach for large or external laryngoceles
  • Avoidance of triggers (e.g., blowing instruments, chronic straining)

Explanation for other options:

Thyroglossal cyst (Option B) is a midline swelling formed due to non-obliteration of the thyroglossal tract.

A branchial cyst (Option C) is formed due to non-obliteration of the second branchial cleft. It presents as lateral neck swelling in childhood or early adulthood with an increase in size following an episode of upper respiratory infection.

Ranula (Option D) is a mucus extravasation cyst of sublingual glands, which presents as a bluish translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about Reinke's oedema?
a. Usually unilateral
b. Common in smokers
c. Corticosteroid is the mainstay of treatment
d. Involve the whole of the membranous part of the vocal cords
e. Patient has dysphonia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reinke's oedema refers to the accumulation of fluid in Reinke's space, which is a potential space in the superficial layer of the lamina propria of the true vocal cords.

It presents as a fusiform (spindle-shaped), bilateral swelling of the vocal cords and is commonly associated with:

  • Chronic smoking (hence the term "Smoker's larynx")
  • Vocal abuse (e.g., shouting, excessive talking)
  • Voice changes, especially hoarseness and a low-pitched voice

Key Features:

  • Usually bilateral (not unilateral) (Statement 'a' is false)
  • Involves the entire membranous part of the vocal cords (Statement 'd' is true)
  • Common in smokers (Statement 'b' is true)
  • Patients have dysphonia (Statement 'e' is true)
  • Treatment involves:
    • Smoking cessation
    • Voice therapy
    • Surgical removal (decortication/subepithelial cordectomy) if persistent
  • Corticosteroids are not the mainstay of treatment (Statement 'c' is false)

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents with inspiratory stridor almost since birth. The cry of a baby is normal. The stridor decreases in the prone position. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a typical presentation of laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia:

  • The most common congenital anomaly of the larynx
  • The most common cause of neonatal stridor
  • Also known as congenital laryngeal stridor
  • Caused by excessive flaccidity of supraglottic structures
  • Weakness of aryepiglottic folds, epiglottis, and other supraglottic tissues
  • Leads to inspiratory collapse of supraglottic structures during breathing

Clinical Features

  • Onset: Within the first week of life
  • Stridor:
    • Inspiratory in nature
    • Increases with crying, feeding, or supine position
    • Relieved in prone position
  • Cry is normal - vocal cords are unaffected
  • No cyanosis or feeding difficulty in most cases

Diagnosis

  • Flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy:
    • Reveals supraglottic collapse
    • Characteristic omega (Ω)-shaped epiglottis

Management

  • Conservative: Reassure parents and "wait and watch" approach
  • Prognosis: 90% resolve spontaneously by 12-18 months, complete resolution by 2 years of age
  • Surgical intervention (only in severe cases): Epiglottopexy or supraglottoplasty is indicated in cases of failure to thrive, apnea, or severe airway obstruction

Explanation for other options:

Vocal Cord Palsy (Option A) typically presents with a weak or hoarse cry. Bilateral palsy can cause stridor, but the cry is usually abnormal with no positional improvement.

Acute Epiglottitis (Option B) is a sudden-onset, rapidly progressing emergency with high fever, toxic appearance, drooling and muffled voice. Common in older children, not neonates/infants.

Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) (Option C) is caused by viral infection (usually parainfluenza) and occurs in children >6 months to 3 years. Presents with barking cough, stridor and low-grade fever.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child has had persistent dyspnoea and stridor since birth. The cry of the baby is normal. On CT scan of the neck, the subglottic diameter is 2.5 mm, What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital Subglottic Stenosis is the diagnosis based on CT and symptoms.

Subglottic stenosis refers to a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords (subglottic region), leading to airway obstruction and stridor, especially in infants and young children.

Types of subglottic stenosis:

1. Congenital Subglottic Stenosis occurs due to abnormal thickening of cricoid cartilage or fibrous tissue proliferation in the subglottic area (below the vocal cords)

2. Acquired Subglottic Stenosis is commonly caused by:

  • Prolonged endotracheal intubation
  • Trauma during intubation
  • Infections (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, diphtheria)
  • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Wegener's granulomatosis)
  • Radiation therapy

Congenital Subglottic Stenosis:

  • Due to abnormal thickening of the cricoid cartilage or presence of fibrous tissue in the subglottic airway.
  • Located just below the vocal cords, between the glottis and trachea.

Clinical Features:

  • Normal cry (unlike glottic lesions)
  • Stridor, especially during upper respiratory tract infections or exertion
  • No hoarseness, since the vocal cords are not involved

Diagnosis:

  • Suspected in infants with unexplained stridor
  • Confirmed via endoscopy or imaging (CT/MRI)
  • Diagnostic criteria (based on airway diameter):
    • Subglottic diameter < 4 mm in a full-term neonate
    • Subglottic diameter < 3 mm in a preterm neonate

Management:

  • Mild cases: May improve with age as the larynx enlarges
  • Moderate to severe cases: May require endoscopic dilation, laser therapy, or open surgical reconstruction (e.g., cricoid split, laryngotracheoplasty)

Explanation for other options:

Congenital Laryngeal web (Option A): A laryngeal web is typically a thin membrane at the glottic level (true vocal cords), presenting with a weak or hoarse cry,

Laryngeal paralysis (Option B): Paralysis of the vocal cords (especially bilateral) can lead to stridor, weak or absent cry and aspiration or feeding difficulties.

Congenital subglottic hemangioma (Option C): Congenital Subglottic Hemangioma is a vascular tumour that usually presents around 6–12 weeks of age (not at birth) and causes progressive stridor and respiratory distress.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male, a chronic smoker, presents to the ENT outpatient department with a 3-month history of hoarseness of voice. He denies pain, dysphagia, or weight loss. Laryngeal endoscopy reveals the following findings. Based on the clinical history and endoscopic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical history and endoscopic findings, the most likely diagnosis is Reinke's oedema.

  • Bilateral & symmetrical fusiform swelling of the vocal cords
  • Common in middle-aged smokers
  • May also occur in hypothyroidism (myxoedema)
  • Hoarseness is the primary symptom
  • Patients often use false vocal cords for phonation, resulting in a low-pitched, rough voice
  • Indirect laryngoscopy shows:
    1. Pale, translucent, balloon-like swelling of the vocal cords
    2. Involvement of the entire membranous part of the cords

Explanation for other options:

Normal vocal cords (Option A): The presence of a visible lesion and clinical hoarseness rules this out.

Vocal polyp (Option B): Unilateral polyp at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and the posterior 2/3rd

Intubation granuloma (Option D): Bilateral granuloma following intubation.

choices.text: The cricoid is a complete, ring-like cartilage
Thyroid angle in females is 120 degrees
Sensory supply of the infraglottic larynx is by the internal laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the anatomy of the larynx
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The infraglottic region (below the vocal cords) is supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

The Larynx

  • The larynx, also known as the voice box, is a cartilaginous structure located in the anterior neck.
  • It serves three primary functions: breathing, swallowing, and phonation (voice production).
  • Located between the pharynx (above) and the trachea (below).
  • In adults, it is typically situated between C3 and C6 vertebral levels.

Cartilages of the Larynx

  • Three Unpaired Cartilages: Thyroid cartilage, cricoid cartilage and epiglottis.
  • Three Paired Cartilages: Arytenoid cartilages, corniculate and cuneiform cartilages.

Vocal Cords and Glottis

  • True vocal cords (glottis): White in appearance; involved in sound production.
  • False vocal cords (vestibular folds): Pink in appearance; do not produce sound, part of the supraglottic area.
  • Glottis: Refers to the space between the true vocal cords.

Vocal Cord Attachments:

  • Anteriorly: Attached to the thyroid cartilage at the midpoint.
  • Posteriorly: Attached to the arytenoid cartilages.

Commissures:

  • Anterior commissure: Where the vocal cords meet anteriorly; covered by mucosa near the epiglottis.
  • Posterior commissure (interarytenoid area): Space between the two arytenoids.

Muscles of the Larynx

  • Intrinsic Muscles - control vocal cord movement
  • Extrinsic Muscles - Move the larynx as a whole (e.g., during swallowing)

Nerve Supply of the Larynx

  • Motor Supply: Recurrent laryngeal nerve for all intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
  • Sensory Supply: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve for supraglottis and the recurrent laryngeal nerve for subglottis

Membranes and Ligaments

  • Thyrohyoid membrane: Connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone and is pierced by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Cricothyroid membrane: Site for emergency airway (cricothyrotomy).

Sex Differences in the Larynx

  • Males: Thyroid angle: ~90° (More prominent Adam's apple). Vocal cord length: 18-23 mm for a deeper voice.
  • Females: Thyroid angle: ~120° (Flatter larynx profile). Vocal cord length: 16-17 mm for a higher-pitched voice.

Explanation for other options:

The cricoid is a complete, ring-like cartilage (Option A): The cricoid cartilage is the only complete ring in the airway, located below the thyroid cartilage.

Thyroid angle in females is 120 degrees (Option B): In females, the thyroid laminae form a wider angle (~120°), which makes the laryngeal prominence less visible than in males.

The interarytenoid muscle is unpaired (Option D): The interarytenoid muscle is the only unpaired intrinsic muscle of the larynx, connecting the two arytenoid cartilages and aiding in vocal cord adduction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT clinic complaining of a rough, hoarse voice for several months. He works as a street vendor and reports frequent vocal strain. On laryngoscopic examination, the true vocal cords appear structurally normal, but there is evidence of compensatory phonation from an abnormal site above the vocal cords. Which structure is causing phonation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This condition is dysphonia plica ventricularis

  • In Dysphonia plica ventricularis/Ventricular dysphonia, the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) are used abnormally for phonation instead of the true vocal cords.
  • False vocal cords and ventricular bands are rudimentary structures in the supraglottis.
  • Voice is rough, low-pitched, and unpleasant.

Explanation for other options:

True vocal cords (Option A): These are the normal site of phonation, but in this case, they are structurally normal but not being used effectively.

Ventricle (Option C): This is the space between the true and false cords, not a phonating structure.

Palatopharyngeal fold (Option D): This is part of the oropharynx and not involved in laryngeal phonation.

choices.text: The most common site is the subglottis
CO2 Laser is helpful in its management
McNaught Keel is used to prevent the reformation of the web

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric ENT clinic with complaints of a weak cry since birth and increasing respiratory difficulty while playing, and a history of recurrent episodes of stridor, especially when crying or during URTIs. On laryngoscopy, a thin membranous structure is seen stretching across the glottis. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child likely has a congenital laryngeal web, a rare condition resulting from incomplete recanalisation of the laryngeal lumen during embryonic development.

  • For Laryngeal webs, the glottis is the most common site.

Laryngeal Web:

  • Usually congenital, though it may be acquired post-intubation or trauma
  • Symptoms:
    • Hoarse or weak cry
    • Stridor
    • Airway obstruction in severe cases
  • Laryngoscopy shows a web-like membrane across the vocal cords

Management:

  • Depends on the thickness of the web:
    • Thin webs: Divided using CO2laser or cold knife
    • Thick webs: Managed by laryngofissure with placement of a silicone keel (McNaught keel) to prevent recurrence and maintain patency

Explanation for other options:

It may cause airway obstruction (Option B): Depending on the size and thickness, laryngeal webs can cause partial or complete airway obstruction, especially in children.

CO2 Laser is helpful in its management (Option C): Thin webs can be precisely excised using a CO2 laser.

McNaught Keel is used to prevent the reformation of web (Option D): In thick webs, after surgical excision, a silicone keel (McNaught Keel) is placed to prevent re-adhesion and recurrence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man visits the ENT clinic for evaluation of throat discomfort. On examination, the clinician gently moves the larynx from side to side over the cervical spine and notes a characteristic grating sensation. There is no tenderness or swelling, and no history of trauma or malignancy. This Laryngeal crepitus is most likely seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laryngeal Crepitus is the grating sensation experienced while moving the Thyroid cartilage over the underlying cervical vertebra.

  • In a normal person, this movement causes air-filled cartilaginous structures (especially the thyroid cartilage) to rub slightly against the cervical vertebrae, producing a grating or crepitant feel.
  • It is a normal clinical finding and indicates no fixation or mass effect behind the larynx.
  • Absence of laryngeal crepitus is called Moure's sign.

Laryngeal Crepitus is absent in

  1. Fractures of thyroid cartilage (Option B): Crepitus may be absent due to pain, swelling, or disruption of anatomical integrity. Movement is often limited and tender.
  2. Post-cricoid carcinoma (Option C): The tumour may fix the larynx to the prevertebral fascia, eliminating laryngeal crepitus. Loss of crepitus is an important sign of post-cricoid or hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
  3. Prevertebral abscess (Option D): The larynx becomes fixed due to inflammation or pus in the prevertebral space. Hence, no crepitus is appreciated.
  4. Retropharyngeal abscess

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a recent URTI history is brought to the ER with noisy breathing and difficulty inhaling, especially when agitated. On examination, inspiratory stridor is noted. Which of the following levels of airway obstruction is most likely responsible for the inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound heard during inhalation and is typically associated with obstruction at or above the level of the vocal cords (glottis), i.e., supraglottic or glottic regions.

  • In young children, the supraglottic area is the narrowest and most vulnerable to swelling during upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs), making it a common site for obstruction.
  • Stridor means noisy breathing, which is due to airway obstruction.

Explanation for other options:

Subglottic obstruction (Option A): This typically causes biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) and is more characteristic of croup.

Glottic obstruction (Option C): This can cause inspiratory or biphasic stridor, but the glottis is less commonly the primary site unless there is vocal cord paralysis or trauma.

Tracheal obstruction (Option D): Tracheal obstruction typically results in expiratory stridor or biphasic stridor, often accompanied by deeper, more coarse breathing sounds.

questions.text: Which cartilage of the larynx is paired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The larynx is composed of 9 cartilages: 3 unpaired and 3 paired

Paired cartilages:

  1. Arytenoid
  2. Corniculate
  3. Cuneiform

These are small cartilages involved in vocal cord movement and support.

Unpaired cartilages:

  1. Thyroid (Option A): Unpaired. It is the largest cartilage and forms the Adam's apple.
  2. Cricoid (Option B): Unpaired. A complete ring of cartilage below the thyroid cartilage.
  3. Epiglottis (Option D): Unpaired. Leaf-shaped cartilage that covers the glottis during swallowing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the ENT outpatient department with progressive hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. He denies pain or difficulty in swallowing. Laryngoscopic examination reveals white, thickened, plaque-like lesions on the true vocal cords. A provisional diagnosis of keratosis larynx is made. What is the ideal treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ideal treatment for keratosis larynx is microlaryngoscopic stripping (excision) of the lesion, followed by histopathological examination to rule out dysplasia or carcinoma in situ.

  • Eliminating chronic irritants, cessation of smoking, treating GERD, voice rest and hygiene can improve symptoms

Keratosis larynx

Etiology:

  • Chronic irritation of the laryngeal mucosa, often due to:
  • Smoking
  • Alcohol use
  • Vocal abuse
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Exposure to environmental toxins

Pathology:

  • Represents epithelial hyperplasia of the vocal cord mucosa.
  • Appears as a white plaque or warty growth on the true vocal cords.
  • It is considered a precancerous lesion (dysplasia or carcinoma in situ may be present).

Clinical Features:

  • Hoarseness of voice (most common symptom)
  • Usually painless
  • No difficulty in swallowing
  • Vocal cord mobility is preserved

Explanation for other options:

Antibiotics and steroids (Option A): These are not effective because keratosis is a non-infective, non-inflammatory epithelial hyperplasia, not requiring antimicrobial or anti-inflammatory treatment.

Steroids only (Option B): Steroids are ineffective as keratosis is a precancerous structural lesion, not an inflammatory or allergic condition responsive to steroids.

Speech therapy (Option C): Speech therapy may help in general vocal hygiene, but it is not a curative treatment for keratosis. The lesion needs to be surgically excised and examined for malignancy.
